title: 103_s1899
content:
There are no paragraphs provided in the prev_chunk, so I will summarize the curr_chunk as follows:

"SECTION 1. FINDINGS." The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia is recognized for its unspoiled areas, excellent water quality, historic landscapes, mill structures, and parks. It connects three national historic districts and two landmarks. The Augusta Canal National Landmark in Georgia includes mill villages, parks, historic districts, and landmarks connected by the Augusta Canal Area. It showcases rural landscapes, scenic vistas, and water quality, representing the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. The Augusta Canal and related mill sites represent the development of the cotton textile industry in the South. The area also includes significant sites associated with various historical events and diverse cultural groups. Despite conservation efforts, the cultural, historical, natural, and recreational aspects of the area are still at risk. The Augusta Canal area, home to Americans of various backgrounds, is in need of assistance to fully realize its cultural, historical, and recreational potential. The Secretary of the Interior has designated it a priority for protection, and there is a strong desire from local agencies and citizens to work together to preserve and enhance its resources. The purpose of this Act is to establish a cooperative management framework for the Augusta Canal in Georgia to retain, enhance, and interpret its significant features while promoting positive economic impact and development. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area boundaries will be established to benefit present and future generations. The Augusta Canal National Heritage Area is established in Georgia and South Carolina, including lands known as the Augusta Canal. The boundaries are outlined in the Augusta Canal Master Plan, with a detailed description and map to be published by the Secretary of the Interior. Additionally, the Augusta Canal Commission is established. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities, including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities, including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members and fills vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment process. The Augusta Canal Commission is established with members appointed from various entities, including the Augusta Canal Authority, the mayor of Augusta, Georgia, the Georgia congressional delegation, the Governor of Georgia, and the Governor of South Carolina. The Commission elects a chairman from its members and fills vacancies in the same manner as the original appointment process. SEC. 5. MANAGEMENT PLAN. The Augusta Canal Commission is required to prepare a management plan for the Heritage Area within 1 year of the Act's enactment. The plan must integrate existing Federal, State, and local plans, including the Augusta Canal Master Plan, to protect and enhance the area's resources. The Secretary can offer technical and financial assistance for plan preparation, and must approve the submitted plan within 180 days. The Secretary can provide technical and financial assistance for the preparation of the management plan for the Heritage Area. Within 180 days of receiving the plan, the Secretary must approve or disapprove it based on criteria such as local support and economic compatibility. The management plan for the Heritage Area must have support from various stakeholders, be economically compatible, have potential for effective partnerships, respect private property rights, and ensure their observance. If the plan is disapproved, the Secretary will notify the Augusta Canal Commission in writing. The Augusta Canal Commission must revise and resubmit the management plan if disapproved by the Secretary, who will provide reasons for disapproval and recommendations for revision. The Commission has 180 days to resubmit the plan for approval. Upon approval of the management plan by the Secretary, steps will be taken to implement it in cooperation with the Augusta Canal Commission. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with various entities to carry out the plan. The Secretary is authorized to enter into cooperative agreements with the State of Georgia, political subdivisions, the Augusta Canal Commission, or any organization to implement the management plan. Economic development in the area should be encouraged by the Augusta Commission, the State of Georgia, the city of Augusta, or any political subdivision, consistent with the goals of the Augusta Canal Master Plan. SEC. 6. ENVIRONMENTAL STANDARDS. This Act does not impose stricter regulations on the Heritage Area than those in place before its establishment. No Federal agency can introduce more stringent regulations solely due to the Heritage Area's creation. SEC. 7. DUTIES OF OTHER FEDERAL ENTITIES. SEC. 7. Duties of other Federal entities include consulting, cooperating, and coordinating activities with the Secretary and Augusta Canal Commission to avoid adverse effects on the Heritage Area. SEC. 8. Authorization of appropriations for carrying out this Act.
